importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The research voyage by CSIRO scientists in the Gascoyne Marine Park took place in late 2022, marking the start of the discovery of new deep-sea species, including the West Australian Lantern Shark and the new porcelain crab.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The discovery period spans from late 2022 to the present, during which scientists have identified over 20 new species, with estimates suggesting around 600 more remain to be described, highlighting ongoing scientific exploration.

keyTakeAways: A semi-transparent porcelain crab, about 1.5cm in size, was discovered at a depth of 122 meters in the Gascoyne Marine Park off Western Australia.
A new species of lantern shark, the West Australian Lantern Shark, was found at over 600 meters below sea level and grows up to 40cm in length, with bioluminescent features on its belly and flanks.

The discoveries are part of a larger effort by Australian scientists from CSIRO to explore uncharted deep-sea regions in Australia’s waters, which are known for high biodiversity and significant unexplored habitats.
About 20 new species have been formally described from the 2022 expedition, including the Carnavon Flapjack Octopus, a rusty red octopus around 4cm in size.
Scientists estimate that approximately 600 more species remain to be described and named due to the lengthy process required to confirm biological uniqueness.
Porcelain crabs are filter feeders using long hairs to catch plankton instead of using claws, a notable adaptation in deep-sea environments.
Lantern sharks are bioluminescent, producing light via photophores on their belly and flanks, which is central to their identification and naming.

namedEntities.name: Australia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nation with high biodiversity, home to over a million species, many endemic to its waters.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Australia is a major biodiversity hotspot, making it a key location for discovering new species, especially in unexplored deep-sea regions.

namedEntities.name: CSIRO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Australia's national science agency conducting deep-sea research.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CSIRO led the 2022 research voyage in the Gascoyne Marine Park, directly responsible for the discovery of new deep-sea species.

namedEntities.name: Gascoyne Marine Park
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A marine protected area located about 20km off the coast of Western Australia.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The research expedition took place in this marine park, which is a key site for deep-sea exploration and species discovery.

namedEntities.name: West Australian Lantern Shark
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly described species of lantern shark found at over 600 meters below sea level.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This species is one of the two new species identified in the deep sea, exhibiting bioluminescence and large eyes, contributing to understanding of deep-sea adaptations.

namedEntities.name: Porcelain crab
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A new type of porcelain crab, about 1.5cm long, found at 122 meters depth.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This species showcases a unique feeding mechanism using hairs instead of claws, a key adaptation to deep-sea environments.

namedEntities.name: Carnavon Flapjack Octopus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly discovered, rusty red octopus around 4cm in size.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the 20 new species identified during the expedition, indicating a rich and diverse deep-sea fauna.

namedEntities.name: Dr Will White
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A fish scientist from CSIRO who commented on the bioluminescent features of lantern sharks.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dr White provided scientific insight into the bioluminescence of lantern sharks, contributing to the understanding of their biology.

namedEntities.name: Dr Andrew Hosie
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Curator of aquatic zoology at the Western Australian Museum who explained the feeding behavior of porcelain crabs.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dr Hosie explained the unique filter-feeding mechanism of porcelain crabs, enhancing scientific understanding of their adaptation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Australian scientists from CSIRO have discovered two new species in the deep sea off Western Australia during a 2022 expedition in the Gascoyne Marine Park. These include a semi-transparent porcelain crab, about 1.5cm long, found at 122 meters depth, which feeds using long hairs to catch plankton, and a new lantern shark species, the West Australian Lantern Shark, found over 600 meters below sea level, growing up to 40cm with bioluminescent features. The discoveries highlight Australia’s status as a biodiversity hotspot and the vast amount of unexplored marine life, with around 600 more species estimated to remain to be described. Scientists emphasize that the deep-sea environment, particularly in protected areas like the Gascoyne Marine Park, remains a frontier for biological discovery.
title: Australia: Almond-sized crab and tiny lantern shark discovered in deep seas
